title: YAML and JSON Configuration Formats
question: What are YAML and JSON? When would you use each format in DevOps?
answer: YAML (YAML Ain't Markup Language) and JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) are data serialization formats. YAML is human-readable with indentation-based syntax, supports comments, and is preferred for configuration files (Kubernetes, Ansible, CI/CD). JSON is more compact, has strict syntax, and is preferred for APIs and machine-to-machine communication. Both represent the same data structures: objects/maps, arrays/lists, and scalar values.
explanation: DevOps engineers work with YAML and JSON daily. Kubernetes manifests, Helm charts, GitHub Actions, and Ansible playbooks all use YAML. APIs typically return JSON. Understanding both formats and being able to convert between them is essential. Common pitfalls include YAML indentation errors and JSON trailing commas.

codeExamples.label: YAML example
codeExamples.code:
# YAML supports comments
app:
  name: myapp
  version: 1.0.0
  
  # Nested configuration
  database:
    host: localhost
    port: 5432
    
  # List/array
  environments:
    - development
    - staging
    - production
    
  # Boolean and null
  enabled: true
  deprecated: false
  optional_field: null
  
  # Multi-line string
  description: |
    This is a multi-line
    description block.
